block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. ''Lon Chaney: Man of a Thousand Faces,'' through Oct. 29. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Maurice Tourneur's ''Victory'' (1919); at 4 p.m., Roland West's ''Monster'' (1925). Sunday at 2 p.m., Tod Browning's ''Unknown'' (1927), with live music by the Transparent Quartet; at 4 p.m., Rupert Julian's ''Phantom of the Opera'' (1925). Repertory nights: tomorrow at 7:30, Reginald Barker's ''Italian'' (1915), music and film program with live music by Donald Sosin and Joanna Seaton. Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Roberto Rossellini's ''Voyage to Italy'' (1953). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

FRAUNCES TAVERN MUSEUM, 54 Pearl Street, second floor, Lower Manhattan. The museum, in a former tavern, is dedicated to the study and interpretation of early American history and culture. Among the period-room displays is the Long Room, the site of Washington's Farewell Address. Other permanent exhibitions are the Clinton Room, named for George Clinton, the first American-born New York governor, and a re-creation of an early 19th-century private dining room. ''The Only Pleasure an American Knows: Politics in 1800,'' including inaugural speeches, paintings and political documents, through Dec. 31. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m.; closed Saturdays and Sundays. Admission: $2.50; $1 for students, children and the elderly; children under 6, free. Information: (212) 425-1778.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the city's history. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a presentation that looks at Puerto Rico's military history. Sunday at 2 p.m., concert of Puerto Rican songs, with several singers accompanied by Eric Plaks, pianist. ''Painting the Town, Cityscapes of New York,'' through Dec. 31. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through today. Monday night at 6, a screening of Andrzej Wajda's ''Korczak,'' followed by a discussion. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts and exhibitions in other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. ''Madison Avenue Goes to Washington: The History of Presidential Campaign Advertising,'' historically significant presidential commercials created between 1952 and 1996, Tuesdays through Sundays at 2 p.m. through Nov. 12. ''Monster in the Box: Horror on Television,'' a series focusing on five decades of the genre, through Dec. 10. This weekend and through Oct. 29, it will focus on the relationship between horror and humor, featuring episodes of the ''The Munsters,'' ''The Addams Family'' and ''The Simpsons''; Fridays at 7 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays at 4 p.m.; Thursdays at 6 p.m. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW YORK TRANSIT MUSEUM, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, downtown Brooklyn. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., ''Transformation Through Transportation,'' an illustrated lecture about New Jersey Transit's Hudson-Bergen Light Rail. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $3; the elderly and ages 6 to 17, $1.50; 5 and under, free. On Wednesdays from noon to 4 p.m., free for the elderly. Information: (718) 243-8601.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open, and guided tours are available. Tomorrow from 2:30 to 4:30 p.m., a presentation on tree care for consumers. Tickets: $19; $15 for members. Free tours Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m.; meet at the Visitors Center. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The fall flower exhibition, including asters, sedums, fall-blooming roses and beech foliage, through mid-November. ''Autumn Garden: Momijigari,'' an outdoor exhibition in the Haupt Conservatory, capturing the look of a traditional Japanese garden, including Japanese maples, conifers, bonsai and, beginning Tuesday, a display of chrysanthemums in traditional Japanese styles. Sunday from 2 to 4 p.m., ''Halloween on Haunted Walk,'' with the puppeteer Ralph Lee, including a man-size walking pumpkin, a 10-foot-tall spider and tap-dancing skeletons. Scarecrow exhibition through Nov. 5. A bonsai exhibition is on view in the Haupt Conservatory through Oct. 29. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical Garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children 2 to 12, $2; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Information: (718) 817-8700.
RECREATION

''MINDS IN MOTION'' 5K WALK AND FORUM, Battery Park. Begins Sunday at 10 a.m.; registration at 9 a.m. at Castle Clinton. Registration fee, $25; proceeds benefit the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill and the National Depressive and Manic-Depressive Association. Sponsored by Pfizer and the Women's Sports Foundation. Information: (800) 890-1100.

BODY-MIND WORKSHOP, Central Park, North Meadow Recreation Center, midpark at 97th Street. One in a series of free events to introduce participants to various fitness programs. Tomorrow at 11 a.m., West African dance will be featured. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 348-4867.
EVENTS

INTERNATIONAL VINTAGE POSTER FAIR, Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, Manhattan. With lectures and panel discussions. Today, 5 to 9 p.m.; tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission, $12 a day; $20 for two days; $30 for all weekend. Information: (800) 856-8069.

''A TASTE OF THE DINING CONCOURSE,'' Grand Central Terminal. With sampling of foods from vendors, as well as entertainment and cooking demonstrations. Today, 3 to 9 p.m.; tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. Tickets are $10, including samples at participating vendors, and may be purchased at the Dining Concourse Booth. Information: (212) 340-2210.

''IN AND ABOUT TOMPKINS SQUARE PARK: WALKS AND TALKS,'' Parks Building, Ninth Street and Avenue B, Lower East Side. With talks on the history of the park and famous people who have spent time there. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Donations accepted. Sponsored by the East Village Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 353-9063.

''TOUGH GUYS, TOUGH GALS, TOUGH CITY: THE PRIVATE EYE FICTION OF NEW YORK,'' New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, Manhattan. A symposium featuring writers and scholars. Sponsored by the New-York Historical Society and the Mercantile Library. Tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $50. Information: (212) 755-6710.

TRAIN RIDE, aboard vintage trains along the Harlem and Hudson lines of Metro-North. Meets tomorrow at 8 a.m. at the main information booth in Grand Central Terminal. Sponsored by the New York Division of the Electric Railroaders' Association. Fee: $60. Information: (718) 784-3643.
ON THE STREET

''CRAFTS ON COLUMBUS,'' Columbus Avenue from 77th to 81st Streets and the sidewalk along 81st Street from Columbus Avenue to the American Museum of Natural History, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance.
GREENWICH AVENUE AUTUMN FESTIVAL, from Christopher Street to Seventh Avenue. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Federation to Preserve the Greenwich Village Waterfront and Great Port.
ST. MARKS VILLAGE FAIR, St. Marks Place, from First to Second Avenues, East Village. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Holy Cross Polish National Church.
23RD STREET FALL FESTIVAL, from Seventh to Eighth Avenues, Chelsea. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the 10th Precinct Community Council.
WORLD MISSIONS STREET FAIR, 51st Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Times Square Church/World Aid New York.
LEXINGTON AVENUE FALL FESTIVAL, from 34th to 42nd Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Soldiers', Sailors' and Airmen's Club.
10TH BROADWAY FALL FESTIVAL, from 86th to 96th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Mid-Manhattan Branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
FRESH POND ROAD FESTIVAL, Fresh Pond Road, from Catalpa to Woodbine Streets, Queens. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Fresh Pond Chamber of Commerce.
WALKING TOURS

''THE FLATIRON DISTRICT: MADISON SQUARE PARK AND ENVIRONS,'' Manhattan. An architectural and historical tour that includes statuary. Meets today at 11 a.m. at the northwest corner of Park Avenue South and 23rd Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10; $8 for students, the elderly and society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''HIKE NEW YORK CITY,'' a six- to eight-mile hike of Manhattan, Midtown and Downtown, with commentary on its history and folklore. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. at the visitors' entrance to the United Nations, First Avenue and 45th Street. Fee: $25 plus refreshments. Led by Michael Kaback. Information: (212) 370-4214.

''SUBWAY SERIES: YANKEE-DODGER WALKING TOUR,'' Upper West Side and Brooklyn Heights. A walk in Manhattan past sites associated with Babe Ruth and Joe DiMaggio, followed by a subway ride to Brooklyn and places frequented by Jackie Robinson and Duke Snider. Tomorrow and Sunday at 3:15 p.m. Fee, $12, plus subway fare. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. For meeting place and reservations: (212) 465-3331.

''SOHO GHOSTS,'' a search for ghosts amid historic buildings. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, Mott and Prince Streets. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Fee: $10. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''EDGAR ALLAN POE AND HIS GHOSTLY FRIENDS,'' Greenwich Village and the East Village. Explore the neighborhoods and learn about the ghosts of Poe, Peter Stuyvesant and others. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. outside the Second Avenue Deli, 156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil's New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

''HARLEM: KEYSTONE OF AFRICAN AMERICA.'' The history, homes, churches and cultural and economic growth of the area. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at City College, Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''OLD ASTORIA VILLAGE,'' Queens. Includes a look at 19th-century mansions, the waterfront and one of the city's last beer gardens. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. outside the Neptune Diner, Hoyt Avenue and 31st Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Historic New York Tours. Information: (718) 729-4055.

''THE NEW TIMES SQUARE: A VITAL CENTER REBORN OR DISNEYLAND NORTH?'' Examines the social and physical changes in the area. Tomorrow at 3 p.m. Sponsored by Cooper Union. Fee, $15. Information and meeting place: (212) 353-4195.

''BROOKLYN'S MUSIC SCENE THROUGH TIME AND SPACE.'' Passes by the site of the old Paramount Theater, as well as the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. Meets tomorrow at 1:30 p.m. outside the gym at the Brooklyn campus of the Long Island University, Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for Center members. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''JOE SENT ME: A HISTORIC SPEAKEASY TOUR'' explores three former speakeasies in SoHo and Greenwich Village. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m., at the southeast corner of Prince Street and Broadway, SoHo. Fee: $10, not including beverages. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''CENTRAL PARK IN AUTUMN,'' with stops at Strawberry Fields, the Literary Walk and Bethesda Fountain. Tomorrow and Sunday at 12:45 p.m. Fee, $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Tours. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 465-3331.

JAMAICA BAY TO FORT TILDEN. An eight-mile walk along Broad Channel to the ocean. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. at the Broad Channel stop of the A train, in Queens. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Fee, $3. Information: (718) 482-9659.

''RESERVOIR ROUNDABOUT,'' Central Park. Incorporates a discussion of the reservoir's history with a look at the landscape. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at Fifth Avenue and East 90th Street. Free. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 310-2727.

GRAVESEND, BROOKLYN. Passes historic houses dating from the Colonial period. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. at Kings Highway and McDonald Avenue. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (718) 338-8564.

''GHOSTS ON BROADWAY.'' Haunted theaters and a hotel. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. in front of the Belasco Theater, 44th Street near Avenue of the Americas. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

PELHAM BAY PARK, the Bronx. A six-mile walk through scenic terrain. Meets Sunday at 10:30 a.m. at the Pelham Bay stop on the No. 6 train. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (718) 998-3793.

''LOWER EAST SIDE: HOME OF THE IMMIGRANTS,'' with stops at the birthplace of Ira Gershwin, the Eldridge Street Synagogue and the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the southwest corner of Forsythe and Grand Streets. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

''SOHO AND NOLITA,'' Lower Manhattan. Trace the evolution of the area from farmland to Italian neighborhood to gallery and boutique mecca. Stops include the ''little'' Singer building, Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, and sites associated with Emma Goldman and Keith Haring. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the southeast corner of Spring and Lafayette Streets. Fee: $10; $8 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439- 1090.

DUMBO AND FULTON FERRY. Covers the city's rapidly developing waterfront. Meets Sunday at 10:30 a.m on the corner of Old Fulton and Water Streets, Brooklyn. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''IDYLLIC ISLAND,'' Roosevelt Island. Meets Sunday at 3:30 p.m. on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and 59th Street. Fee: $5 and $3 round-trip tramway fare. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''BEAUTY UNDERFOOT,'' Upper West Side. A tour of manhole covers found in the neighborhood. Sunday at 2 p.m. Sponsored by the New-York Historical Society. Free with society admission: $5; $3 for students and the elderly; free for those under 12. Information and meeting place: (212) 873-3400.

GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY, Brooklyn, a two-hour walk through the cemetery where Currier and Ives, Horace Greeley, Samuel F. B. Morse, Louis Comfort Tiffany, Leonard Bernstein and others are buried. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. inside the Fort Hamilton Parkway gate off McDonald Avenue. Fee: $6. Led by John J. Cashman and Frank Mescall. Information: (718) 469-5277.

HARLEM. Stops on this tour include the Black Panther headquarters, the Langston Hughes House and Marcus Garvey Park. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at 306 Malcolm X Boulevard, at 125th Street. Sponsored by Radical Walking Tours. Fee: $10. Information: (718) 492-0069.
